text:
ok, guys, i finally solve this, i had to reinstall the whole laptop from my company and it seems working.
i have to made a change to
```    def _create_socket(self) -> socket.socket:
        """Creates ssl socket, connects to stream api and
        sets timeout.
        """
        sock = socket.create_connection((self.host, self.__port),self.timeout)
        context = ssl.create_default_context()
        sslsock = context.wrap_socket(sock, server_hostname=self.host)
        #s = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
        #s = ssl.wrap_socket(s)
        #s.settimeout(self.timeout)
        #s.connect((self.host, self.__port))
        s = sslsock
        return s```
if it make sense i can push it

elements.text:
ok, guys, i finally solve this, i had to reinstall the whole laptop from my company and it seems working.
i have to made a change to

def _create_socket(self) -> socket.socket:
        """Creates ssl socket, connects to stream api and
        sets timeout.
        """
        sock = socket.create_connection((self.host, self.__port),self.timeout)
        context = ssl.create_default_context()
        sslsock = context.wrap_socket(sock, server_hostname=self.host)
        #s = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
        #s = ssl.wrap_socket(s)
        #s.settimeout(self.timeout)
        #s.connect((self.host, self.__port))
        s = sslsock
        return s
if it make sense i can push it

text: Hey guys! I'm using Flumine to execute my orders & noticing that for a few orders that are traded, in that tick itself the order.size_matched doesn't change. Don't see any bug in my code so far so wanted to confirm if the order details take some time to update or something?

elements.text: Hey guys! I'm using Flumine to execute my orders & noticing that for a few orders that are traded, in that tick itself the order.size_matched doesn't change. Don't see any bug in my code so far so wanted to confirm if the order details take some time to update or something?

text: Got any more context? Live? Simulation? What do you mean by 'that are traded'?

elements.text: Got any more context? Live? Simulation? What do you mean by 'that are traded'?

text: Its live. So lets say a new tick arrives & streaming_update suggests that there's a trade in this tick. market in the last tick was 4.2@4.4 & i was having a back order @4.4. Now in this tick, I check the order.size_remaining for my order & it says its still the same(i.e I didn't get match) & the market in this tick is 4.2@4.5. And my 4.4 order actually got matched

elements.text: Its live. So lets say a new tick arrives & streaming_update suggests that there's a trade in this tick. market in the last tick was 4.2@4.4 & i was having a back order @4.4. Now in this tick, I check the order.size_remaining for my order & it says its still the same(i.e I didn't get match) & the market in this tick is 4.2@4.5. And my 4.4 order actually got matched

text: Are you sure you are at the front of the queue? How are you check the size_remaining? Within process_orders?

elements.text: Are you sure you are at the front of the queue? How are you check the size_remaining? Within process_orders?

text: Not sure about being at the front of the queue but I'm getting a fill for sure because I see it on my bets page. I'm doing all the trading operations in process_market_book, so checking size_remaining in process_market_book. Basically, I'm sending a lot of orders &, so to maintain them properly I save all the orders locally(the order object, & some extra features like size_matched so far etc) & then when a new tick comes I call the order objects that I have saved locally & check the order.size_remaining in process_market_book. Could this be the reason why? In the simulation, this was working fine for me.

Could this be the reason why? In the simulation, this was working fine for me.

text: Yeah there is always a delay between the book and the local order book, the former is normally faster

elements.text: Yeah there is always a delay between the book and the local order book, the former is normally faster

text: Hmmm, just to understand, what's the reason for this. Since I'm calling the object again when I do my_local_object.size_remaining. I don't understand why it'll be different from order.size_remaining in the process_orders

elements.text: Hmmm, just to understand, what's the reason for this. Since I'm calling the object again when I do my_local_object.size_remaining. I don't understand why it'll be different from order.size_remaining in the process_orders

text:
Your order goes through the matching engine at betfair, a new MarketBook is created and sent out to the Market Stream along with an update to your current orders via the Order Stream.

We update the local Order.size_remaining with the data from the Order Stream but this can take a few ms and is sometimes slower from betfair.

elements.text:
Your order goes through the matching engine at betfair, a new MarketBook is created and sent out to the Market Stream along with an update to your current orders via the Order Stream.

We update the local Order.size_remaining with the data from the Order Stream but this can take a few ms and is sometimes slower from betfair.

text: This is why we have `process_market_book` and `process_orders`

process_market_book
and

As you have suggested process_orders is faster, but I can't call it as I need to know what has happened to my orders first & then send orders based on that.

text: All the orders for the market are in the `blotter` so you can see their state from `process_market_book` Not sure exactly how/when the blotter is updated but the order data and market data are totally different BF streams coming from different systems and are not synced in time as far as I know so you can never be 100% sure of your true position at each packet. Middleware _may_ be something useful to consider in your design as shown after the blotter info at  <https://betcode-org.github.io/flumine/markets/#blotter>
